message:
So, following what Adel Khalil did, let's add my post as well.

I'm a 17 years old web developer, started UnliCrea around a couple of years ago. I worked on a lot of projects including the web platform for Concerned Joe and I released an opensource version of the whole thing. We self-fund ourselves by freelancing on oDesk.

I got an internship at eSpace last July and right now I'm working on the project we were working on then. It's an iOS game made using Swift. It's also a clone of another game I created earlier using ActionScript 3 during NewGrounds Game Jam 9.

There are a lot of other stuff to add but I'd rather keep it short. So yea, who'd like to AMA?

data.message: I saw the web site and the company portfolio, just wanted to say Good Job and keep going, you seem to be doing amazing work with Open Source technologies. I would be interested to know about the work you did to teach students programming.

Actually it was a couple of projects and unfortunately they both failed. The first one was our first project ever, it was a new programming language using artificial intelligence. You would be able to teach your computer and code it by talking to it. We wanted to extend beyond that, where you could teach a robot how to dance for example. The project was already created, and has been up for around 18 years or so.

The second thing was a flash game where you had to code to pass the levels. There were not so many libraries at that time that could parse code, or let's say that we were not experienced enough to make something that big. It ended up as being too big for us so we just discontinued the project.

And then we extended past the point of "teaching people programming" when we released CIE Results and started working on big freelancing projects.
Ahmed Raslan
Do you have any tips for getting big projects on oDesk?

Well, just be honest.

On oDesk everyone's deceiving and everyone's lying and everyone wants money even if it's dirty and stained with dishonesty. That gives you a very, very sharp edge and an incredible chance to excel.

On my first job ever my rate got tripled because of how honest I am. Things get even better when you finish stuff reasonably fast, or well, let's just summarize it in 6 words, "when you stop being a bastard". As long as your language is good, your work is clean, your speed is okay, you're not stealing anyone's money, you make sure everything's working, it'll be easy.

And don't get bored. Keep applying and you'll get one of the jobs.

Also, if you're a starter, don't get bloated. Remember that you don't have any reviews there yet and you don't have anything to make you special except your rate, so keep it low until you get a neat number of reviews and then increase it reasonably.
How did you come to learn at this age and what was it like to intern at e-space ?

I started learning Visual Basic at school in the fifth grade. When I was 13 I joined an academy that taught programming. I learned C++ and problem solving there. At the same time I was learning Objective-C because I was crazy enough to think that vimov would accept my application. It took me a year but I learned everything about OOP, thanks to Stanford's CS193p course, and vimov's QA manager, who introduced me to it.

A few months later, around the beginning of 2013, I learned PHP because I wanted to implement CIE Results, and again I was crazy enough to apply for a freelance job. According to the guy, I actually did a job he's been investing in for 2 years, in a couple of weeks, and I had only few months of experience in PHP, if not weeks. I kept going and by the end of the year I was a Startup Weekend Alexandria participant who knows around 8 programming languages.

Starting UnliCrea has another long story but I'd like to mention that the first time I paid for the hosting and the domain I used my "3edeyya".

And also, again, there's a lot of details missing here, like other internships I applied for and got rejected, or other projects including other programming languages such as that Python-PHP socket I made which used to parse Python code. That was around October 2012. However, if I added everything that would make this comment huge.
Good job msA, I am interested to work with you soon isA.
It'd be an honor :)
Whatever you do, don't get cocky

Honestly it's more difficult than it sounds. Most of the time it's just the easier to "get cocky" and swiftly prove that a concept someone suggested is fucked up, because no one's got time to think of a way to explain it without hurting anyone's feelings, you know.
No, I mean keep your head down and always keep the learning mentality, never consider yourself a master at anything
Nah don't worry about that, I'm quite good at proving how big a disappointment I am :D
:) me too :D
WoW. I wish I could be like you 2 years later. I am still 15!
You probably will be far better :D

Mostafa Elgayar install ubuntu, download PyCharm IDE or ERIC IDE, do one of the coursera Python Courses or the Youtube Python coding days :) But start by leavin Windows. You could create a bootable USB drive at first. Ubuntu source iso is only 800 MB I think
After Ubuntu, you can try Debian, but maybe after 1 year with Ubuntu as a hardcore power user

I am learning Python from a MIT Course on edx. I had Ubuntu installed beside Windows but removed it because I preferred Windows. But now I have it running on vMware especially that I don't need it much except when writing Python. Also, I am more good at Web Development so Windows is OKAY in this field... Mohamed Samy
Amjad Hesham Mash'al I hope :)
You can do Python on Windows or Gnu/Linux , but I mean you better learn an OS like Linux as it will add to your skills. Also more stable and you get a better experience with hardware performance.

My own approach is a bit different. I literally have a list of projects and whenever I finish working on one, whether it fails or succeeds, and I have some time to work on another, I just pick another project from there and start working on it. I rate them by how promising they are. And it doesn't matter what does it require. That list actually includes hardware stuff. Although I prefer web development, I'll just dive in and learn whatever it requires and do it.

Doing that succeeded for me, just start working on it and keep fixing bugs until it works and until you learn how does it work.
Learn Bash commands and shell scripts with Python. Maybe even use EMACS, but I am still a beginner in EMACs despite my love for it
^ Nah don't do that. Just pick an editor you like. The argument of editors will always remain hot but in the end everyone uses Sublime.
Oh, and it is all free, no need to pay a company for software. As I believe all books, software and music should be free
